responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) via Plugin Settings
    analysis: |
      The plugin allows administrators to set various settings, including a custom label and a placeholder for the what3words input field. These settings are reflected in the HTML output without proper sanitization.
      An attacker who has gained administrative access to the WordPress site can inject malicious JavaScript code into these settings. This code will then be executed in the browser of any user who visits the affected page, potentially leading to session hijacking, data theft, or other attacks.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - w3w-autosuggest/admin/js/w3w-autosuggest-admin.js
      - w3w-autosuggest/public/js/w3w-autosuggest-public.js
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) in Plugin Settings
    analysis: |
      The plugin does not appear to implement any CSRF protection for its settings page. An attacker could craft a malicious request that, when submitted by an authenticated administrator, would change the plugin's settings without their knowledge or consent.
    cwe: CWE-352
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - w3w-autosuggest/admin/js/w3w-autosuggest-admin.js
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
    analysis: |
      The plugin logs the PHP, WordPress, and WooCommerce versions to the console on the client-side. This information could be used by an attacker to identify potential vulnerabilities in the website's software stack.
    cwe: CWE-200
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - w3w-autosuggest/public/js/w3w-autosuggest-public.js
    classification: not promising
```

leads.headline: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) via Plugin Settings
leads.analysis:
The plugin allows administrators to set various settings, including a custom label and a placeholder for the what3words input field. These settings are reflected in the HTML output without proper sanitization.
An attacker who has gained administrative access to the WordPress site can inject malicious JavaScript code into these settings. This code will then be executed in the browser of any user who visits the affected page, potentially leading to session hijacking, data theft, or other attacks.

leads.headline: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) in Plugin Settings
leads.analysis: The plugin does not appear to implement any CSRF protection for its settings page. An attacker could craft a malicious request that, when submitted by an authenticated administrator, would change the plugin's settings without their knowledge or consent.

leads.headline: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
leads.analysis: The plugin logs the PHP, WordPress, and WooCommerce versions to the console on the client-side. This information could be used by an attacker to identify potential vulnerabilities in the website's software stack.
